    • Wilcoxon-Mann-Whitney Odds

    Wilcoxon-Mann-Whitney Odds

    A Rank Based Hypothesis Test

    wmw_odds.Rmd
    library(ARCmisc)

    Short Background

    As an alternative, or in supplement to, Wilcoxon-Mann-Whitney rank sum/signed rank tests Agresti (1980) and Castelloe and O’Brien (2005) have suggested a measure of effect size in the form of “odds” (Castelloe and O’Brien 2005; Agresti 1980). This can be considered as a transformation of the rank-biserial correlation or the concordance probability1

    Implementation

    This is implemented with the wmw_odds function. It is almost identical to wilcox.test

    Two sample 

    data(sleep)

wmw_otest(extra ~ group,
         data = sleep)
#> 
#>  Two-Sample Wilcoxon-Mann-Whitney Odds
#> 
#> data:  extra by group
#> z = -0.53606, SE for z = 0.26458, p-value = 0.04275
#> alternative hypothesis: true location shift is not equal to 0
#> 95 percent confidence interval:
#>  0.1213306 0.9656004
#> sample estimates:
#>      odds 
#> 0.3422819

    Paired samples 

    data(sleep)

wmw_otest(extra ~ group,
         data = sleep,
         paired = TRUE)
#> 
#>  Paired Samples Wilcoxon-Mann-Whitney Odds
#> 
#> data:  extra by group
#> z = -2.3457, SE for z = 0.35675, p-value = 4.863e-11
#> alternative hypothesis: true location shift is not equal to 0
#> 95 percent confidence interval:
#>  0.002265875 0.037145907
#> sample estimates:
#>        odds 
#> 0.009174312

    One sample 

    data(sleep)

wmw_otest(sleep$extra)
#> 
#>  One-Sample Wilcoxon-Mann-Whitney Odds
#> 
#> data:  sleep$extra
#> z = 0.83982, SE for z = 0.25511, p-value = 0.0009946
#> alternative hypothesis: true location is not equal to 0
#> 95 percent confidence interval:
#>   1.973173 14.579867
#> sample estimates:
#>     odds 
#> 5.363636

    References

    Agresti, Alan. 1980. “Generalized Odds Ratios for Ordinal Data.” Biometrics 36 (1): 59. https://doi.org/10.2307/2530495.
    Castelloe, Ralph, and John O’Brien. 2005. “Exploiting the Link Between the Wilcoxon-Mann-Whitney Test and a Simple Odds Statistic.” http://www.asasrms.org/Proceedings/y2005/files/JSM2005-000930.pdf.

    1. You can see this in blog posts by Frank Harrell or in the effectsize R package↩︎
